answers.content_html: In NH<sub>2</sub>, the nitrogen atom acquires a partial positive charge and the hydrogen atoms acquire a partial negative charge.
answers.feedback_html: Nitrogen, being an electronegative atom, acquires a partial negative charge.

answers.content_html: In H<sub>2</sub>O, the hydrogen atoms acquire a partial negative charge, and the oxygen atom acquires a partial positive charge.
answers.feedback_html: Oxygen will give a partial negative charge because it is so electronegative.

answers.content_html: In aqueous HCl, the hydrogen atom acquires a partial positive charge, and the chlorine atom acquires a partial negative charge.
answers.feedback_html: Aqueous HCl is ionic in nature. Therefore, it does not share electrons and will not show partial charges on its atoms related to unequal electron sharing, as polar covalent compounds can.

answers.content_html: In LiF, the lithium atom acquires a positive charge, and the fluorine atom acquires a negative charge.
answers.feedback_html: Lithium and fluorine form an ionic bond.

stem_html: Based on the information provided, which of the following statements is correct?

answers.content_html: Over time the energy increases and the amplitude gradually reduces to zero. This is called damping.
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure energy increases?

answers.content_html: Over time the energy dissipates and the amplitude gradually increases. This is called damping.
answers.feedback_html: Are you sure amplitude increases?

answers.content_html: Over time the energy increases and the amplitude gradually increases. This is called damping.
answers.feedback_html: What happens to amplitude and energy in damped systems?

answers.content_html: Over time the energy dissipates and the amplitude gradually reduces to zero. This is called damping.
answers.feedback_html: Damping gradually decreases the amplitude of vibration due to dissipation of energy.

answers.content_html: The original hypothesis is correct. There is something wrong with the electrical outlet and therefore the toaster doesn’t work.
answers.feedback_html: The original hypothesis is incorrect because the toaster may be broken or was not turned on.

answers.content_html: The original hypothesis is incorrect. Alternative hypothesis includes that toaster wasn’t turned on.
answers.feedback_html: The original hypothesis is incorrect because when the coffee maker was plugged in it worked. Therefore, it is incorrect to hypothesize that there is something wrong with the outlet. Alternative hypothesis includes that the toaster wasn’t turned on.

answers.content_html: The original hypothesis is correct. The coffee maker and the toaster do not work when plugged into the outlet.
answers.feedback_html: The coffee maker works when plugged into the outlet, but the toaster doesn’t. Alternative hypothesis includes that the toaster wasn’t turned on.

answers.content_html: The original hypothesis is incorrect. Alternative hypotheses includes that both coffee maker and toaster were broken.
answers.feedback_html: The coffee maker works in the mentioned situation but the toaster doesn’t. Alternative hypotheses suggests that the toaster might be broken or was not working.

stem_html:
In the example below, the scientific method is used to solve an everyday problem. Order the scientific method steps (numbered items) with the process of solving the everyday problem (lettered items). Based on the results of the experiment, is the hypothesis correct? If it is incorrect, propose some alternative hypotheses.

  Scientific Method   Everyday process
1 Observation A There is something wrong with the electrical outlet.
2 Question B If something is wrong with the outlet, my coffeemaker also won’t work when plugged into it.
3 Hypothesis (answer) C My toaster doesn’t toast my bread.
4 Prediction D I plug my coffee maker into the outlet.
5 Experiment E My coffeemaker works.
6 Result F What is preventing my toaster from working?

answers.content_html: 640\,\text{Hz}
answers.feedback_html: Beat frequency is given by the modulus of the difference between two frequencies.

answers.content_html: 320\,\text{Hz}
answers.feedback_html: Beat frequency is given by the modulus of the difference between two frequencies.

answers.content_html: 20\,\text{Hz}
answers.feedback_html: Beat frequency is given by the modulus of the difference between two frequencies.

answers.content_html: 40\,\text{Hz}
answers.feedback_html: Beat frequency is given by the modulus of the difference between two frequencies.

stem_html: What is the beat frequency produced by the superposition of two waves with frequencies 300\,\text{Hz} and 340\,\text{Hz}?

answers.content_html: No, beats can be produced only by resonance.
answers.feedback_html: Superposition of sound waves of different frequencies but identical amplitudes can produce beats.

answers.content_html: Yes, beats can be produced by superimposition of any two waves having slightly different frequencies.
answers.feedback_html: The superimposition leads to constructive and destructive interference, producing beats.

stem_html: Can beats be produced through a phenomenon different from resonance? How?

answers.content_html: 2 nodes and 3 antinodes or 2 antinodes and 3 nodes.
answers.feedback_html: One full wavelength will have 3 nodes and 2 antinodes.

answers.content_html: 2 nodes and 2 antinodes or 3 antinodes and 3 nodes.
answers.feedback_html: It is not possible to have 2 nodes and 2 antinodes for a full wavelength.

answers.content_html: 3 nodes and 3 antinodes or 2 antinodes and 2 nodes.
answers.feedback_html: A full wavelength can never have an equal number of nodes and antinodes.

answers.content_html: 6 nodes and 4 antinodes or 6 antinodes and 4 nodes.
answers.feedback_html: This is too many nodes and antinodes.

stem_html: What is the possible number of nodes and antinodes along one full wavelength of a standing wave?

answers.content_html: 1- Inductive, 2- Deductive, 3- Deductive, 4- Inductive
answers.feedback_html: 1- Inductive, 2- Deductive, 3- Deductive, 4- Inductive

answers.content_html: 1- Deductive, 2- Inductive, 3- Deductive, 4- Inductive
answers.feedback_html: Statement 1 is inductive and statement 2 is deductive.

answers.content_html: 1- Inductive, 2- Deductive, 3- Inductive, 4- Deductive
answers.feedback_html: Statement 3 is deductive and statement 4 is inductive.

answers.content_html: 1- Inductive, 2-Inductive, 3- Inductive, 4- Deductive
answers.feedback_html: Statement 2 is deductive, statement 3 is deductive and statement 4 is inductive.

stem_html:
Decide if each of the following is an example of inductive or deductive reasoning.
  1. All flying birds and insects have wings. Birds and insects flap their wings as they move through the air. Therefore, wings enable flight.
  2. Insects generally survive mild winters better than harsh ones. Therefore, insect pests will become more problematic if global temperatures increase.
  3. Chromosomes, the carriers of DNA, separate into daughter cells during cell division. Therefore, DNA is the genetic material.
  4. Animals as diverse as insects and wolves all exhibit social behavior. Therefore, social behavior must have an evolutionary advantage for humans.

answers.content_html: A and B look alike.
answers.feedback_html: Only using morphological similarity cannot be the basis for concluding that two organisms are closely related.

answers.content_html: A and B live in the same ecosystem.
answers.feedback_html: Ecosystem includes many species living together. Just because they share the same ecosystem does not mean the two organisms are closely related.

answers.content_html: A and B use the same metabolic pathways.
answers.feedback_html: Metabolic pathways of living organisms can be similar. This does not serve as basis to conclude that two organisms are closely related.

answers.content_html: The DNA sequences of A and B are highly homologous.
answers.feedback_html: If the DNA sequences of the two organisms share homology, then they can be closely related evolutionarily.

stem_html: Which of the following statements is the strongest argument in favor of two organisms, A and B, being closely related evolutionarily?

answers.content_html: The mitochondria will be the largest as the cell constantly requires energy to keep dividing.
answers.feedback_html: In rapidly dividing cells, mitochondria do not have time to expand as the next round of division starts.

answers.content_html: The nucleus must be the largest as the cell starts to divide since it does not have time to expand.
answers.feedback_html: The nucleus will remain the largest as it will contain the genetic material that constantly divides and cytoplasm will not have time to expand as the next round of division starts . This is typical of cancerous cells and rapidly dividing tissues.

answers.content_html: The endoplasmic reticulum will be the largest as it will constantly provide the essential proteins for the division process.
answers.feedback_html: The endoplasmic reticulum does not expand as protein synthesis is not the major activity.

answers.content_html: The microtubules will the largest as they play a major role in cell division.
answers.feedback_html: Microtubules are small in size and divide each time the cell divides. Other organelles bigger in size than microtubules are present.

stem_html: What organelle would be the largest in rapidly dividing cells?

answers.content_html: They inhibit cell division.
answers.feedback_html: Rb and other proteins negatively regulate the cell cycle.

answers.content_html: They enhance the rate of cell division.
answers.feedback_html: Tumor suppression means inhibition of cell division.

answers.content_html: They start the cell cycle, thereby suppressing tumor formation.
answers.feedback_html: Rb halts the cell cycle and prevents cell division.

answers.content_html: These proteins, when phosphorylated, allow the cell cycle to proceed.
answers.feedback_html: Unphosphorylated Rb binds to E2F and blocks transcription. Thus, the cell cycle does not proceed further.

stem_html: Rb and other proteins that negatively regulate the cell cycle are sometimes called tumor supressors. Why do you think the name tumor suppressor might be appropriate for these proteins?
